slides.title: Introduction to Current Affairs
slides.content:
Current Affairs forms an essential part of General Knowledge for Postal GDS exam. It tests your awareness of recent national and international events, government schemes, sports, awards, and important developments.

**What is Current Affairs?**
Current Affairs includes recent events, news, and developments from the past 6-12 months that have significance at national or international level.

**Topics Covered:**
1. **National Affairs** - Government policies, schemes, appointments
2. **International Affairs** - Global events, treaties, summits
3. **Sports** - Major tournaments, winners, records
4. **Awards and Honors** - Nobel Prize, Padma Awards, etc.
5. **Science and Technology** - New discoveries, launches
6. **Economic Affairs** - Budget, GDP, inflation
7. **Appointments** - New heads of organizations
8. **Books and Authors** - Important publications

**Why Important?**
- 8-10 questions in GK section
- Shows your awareness level
- Based on recent 6-12 months
- Dynamic and changing topic
- Requires regular reading

**How to Prepare:**
- Read newspapers daily (especially editorial pages)
- Follow monthly current affairs magazines
- Watch news channels regularly
- Make notes of important events
- Revise monthly compilations
- Focus on national events more than international

Stay updated with current events to score well in this section.

slides.title: Important Government Schemes
slides.content:
**Major Central Government Schemes (Recent Focus):**

**1. Pradhan Mantri Jan Dhan Yojana (PMJDY)**
- Financial inclusion program
- Provides bank accounts to unbanked households
- Zero balance account with RuPay debit card
- Launched: 28 August 2014

**2. Ayushman Bharat (PM-JAY)**
- Health insurance scheme
- Coverage: ₹5 lakh per family per year
- Covers over 10 crore poor families
- Largest healthcare scheme globally

**3. Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi (PM-KISAN)**
- Direct income support to farmers
- ₹6,000 per year in three installments
- Covers all farmer families

**4. Swachh Bharat Mission**
- Cleanliness and sanitation campaign
- Launched: 2 October 2014
- Aims for clean and open defecation-free India

**5. Digital India Mission**
- Program to transform India digitally
- E-governance, digital infrastructure
- Digital literacy

**6. Make in India**
- Encourage manufacturing in India
- Boost domestic production
- Create jobs

**7. Skill India Mission**
- Skill development for youth
- Multiple training programs
- Employment generation

**8. Beti Bachao Beti Padhao**
- Girl child welfare scheme
- Improve gender ratio
- Promote education for girls

**9. Ujjwala Yojana**
- Free LPG connections to poor households
- Women empowerment

**10. Atal Pension Yojana**
- Pension scheme for unorganized sector
- Monthly pension after 60 years

**Note:** Always stay updated with newly launched schemes and their details.

slides.title: Important Days and Events
slides.content:
**National Important Days:**

**January:**
- 26th: Republic Day
- 30th: Martyrs' Day (Mahatma Gandhi)

**February:**
- 28th: National Science Day

**March:**
- 8th: International Women's Day
- 23rd: Shaheed Diwas (Bhagat Singh)

**April:**
- 5th: National Maritime Day
- 22nd: Earth Day

**May:**
- 1st: Labour Day
- 11th: National Technology Day

**June:**
- 5th: World Environment Day
- 21st: International Yoga Day

**July:**
- 11th: World Population Day

**August:**
- 15th: Independence Day
- 29th: National Sports Day

**September:**
- 5th: Teachers' Day
- 8th: International Literacy Day
- 16th: World Ozone Day

**October:**
- 2nd: Gandhi Jayanti, International Non-Violence Day
- 31st: National Unity Day (Sardar Patel)

**November:**
- 14th: Children's Day (Nehru Jayanti)
- 26th: Constitution Day

**December:**
- 4th: Navy Day
- 16th: Vijay Diwas
- 23rd: Kisan Diwas

**International Days:**
- January 1: New Year
- April 7: World Health Day
- May 1: International Workers' Day
- June 14: World Blood Donor Day
- December 10: Human Rights Day

**Remember dates of national holidays and UN designated international days.**

question.questionText: When is National Sports Day celebrated in India?
question.explanation: National Sports Day is celebrated on 29th August every year to mark the birth anniversary of Major Dhyan Chand, the legendary hockey player.

slides.title: Awards and Honors
slides.content:
**Padma Awards (Republic Day):**

**Padma Vibhushan** - 2nd highest civilian award
**Padma Bhushan** - 3rd highest civilian award
**Padma Shri** - 4th highest civilian award
**Bharat Ratna** - Highest civilian award

**National Awards:**

**1. Gallantry Awards:**
- Param Vir Chakra (Highest wartime)
- Ashok Chakra (Highest peacetime)
- Vir Chakra, Shaurya Chakra

**2. Sports Awards:**
- Rajiv Gandhi Khel Ratna Award (Now Major Dhyan Chand Khel Ratna)
- Arjuna Award
- Dronacharya Award (Coaches)
- Dhyan Chand Award (Lifetime achievement)

**3. Film Awards:**
- Dadasaheb Phalke Award (Cinema)
- National Film Awards
- Filmfare Awards

**4. Literature Awards:**
- Jnanpith Award (Highest literary award)
- Sahitya Akademi Award

**International Awards:**

**Nobel Prize Categories:**
- Physics
- Chemistry
- Medicine/Physiology
- Literature
- Peace
- Economics

**Other International Awards:**
- Booker Prize (Literature)
- Pulitzer Prize (Journalism/Literature)
- Grammy Awards (Music)
- Oscar Awards (Films)
- Ramon Magsaysay Award (Asian Nobel)

**Recent Focus:**
Stay updated on recent winners of major awards, especially Indian recipients of international awards and Padma awardees.

slides.title: Sports Current Affairs
slides.content:
**Major Sports Events:**

**Cricket:**
- ICC World Cup (ODI)
- ICC T20 World Cup
- Indian Premier League (IPL)
- Asia Cup

**Olympics:**
- Summer Olympics (Every 4 years)
- Winter Olympics (Every 4 years)
- Paralympic Games

**Other Major Events:**
- FIFA World Cup (Football)
- Wimbledon (Tennis)
- Asian Games
- Commonwealth Games
- Grand Slam Tennis (Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon, US Open)

**Important Sports Terms:**

**Cricket:**
- Bowled, LBW, Caught, Run out
- Century, Double century
- Hat-trick, Maiden over

**Football:**
- Goal, Penalty, Free kick
- Yellow card, Red card
- Hat-trick, Clean sheet

**Tennis:**
- Love, Deuce, Advantage
- Grand Slam
- Ace, Break point

**Badminton:**
- Smash, Drop shot
- Shuttle, Racquet

**Indian Sports Achievements:**
- Focus on recent medals won
- New records created
- Retirement of legendary players
- Debut performances

**Sports Stadiums in India:**
- Eden Gardens (Kolkata) - Cricket
- Wankhede Stadium (Mumbai) - Cricket
- M. Chinnaswamy Stadium (Bangalore)
- Jawaharlal Nehru Stadium (Delhi)
- Salt Lake Stadium (Kolkata) - Football

**Remember:** Focus on recent tournament winners and Indian achievements in sports.

question.questionText: Which is the highest peacetime gallantry award in India?
question.explanation: Ashok Chakra is the highest peacetime gallantry award in India. Param Vir Chakra is the highest wartime gallantry award.

slides.title: Current Affairs Preparation Strategy
slides.content:
**Daily Routine:**

**Morning (30 minutes):**
- Read newspaper (The Hindu/Indian Express)
- Focus on national news, government decisions
- Note important appointments
- Check sports section

**Weekly (1-2 hours):**
- Compile important news of the week
- Make notes of new schemes/policies
- List awards and honors announced
- Note sports results

**Monthly (2-3 hours):**
- Read monthly current affairs magazine
- Revise all important events
- Take monthly current affairs quiz
- Update your notes

**Important Focus Areas:**

**1. Government Decisions:**
- New schemes launched
- Policy changes
- Constitutional amendments
- Budget highlights

**2. Appointments:**
- Heads of important organizations
- Governors, Chief Ministers
- International organization heads
- Ambassadors

**3. Science and Technology:**
- ISRO launches
- New discoveries
- Technology innovations
- Space missions

**4. Economic News:**
- GDP growth rate
- Inflation rate
- RBI policy decisions
- Important economic data

**Exam Preparation Tips:**

**Last Month Before Exam:**
- Focus on last 6 months events
- Revise all monthly compilations
- Take multiple current affairs tests
- Focus on repeated news items
- Make flashcards of important facts

**Important Note:**
Current affairs is 40% newspapers + 40% magazines + 20% online sources. Consistency is more important than intensity.
